content:
Update Log:
Updated the tests with missing test/validator names to be: "Some Repeats X"

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The idea is simple and very visual! I like it!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: There are many test so that's really cool for people and the game is really cool, gj!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good idea!  I love it!

Interesting idea!

Output
* Line 2: Consider changing "different snowflakes" to "distinct snowflake shapes", since "different snowflakes" can be misinterpreted unless it's clearly tied to the rotation/reflection rule.

Goal
* Building on the previous point, consider changing "the same" to "have the same shape".

Constraints
* The lower bounds for [[h]] and [[w]] should probably be 1 instead of 0.

Cases
* Pending. Just a reminder to balance the number of cases across [[h]] = [[w]], [[h]] > [[w]] and [[h]] < [[w]].

Thanks.

Thanks, made your changes and have updated the cases. 

(I still need to come up with a name for tests 15-17)

Let me know if you think anything else needs updating ðŸ™‚

Thank you.

I'm not sure if snowflakes within snowflakes (like this example:

ï¼Žï¼Šï¼Šï¼Šï¼Šï¼Šï¼Ž
ï¼Šï¼Šï¼Žï¼Žï¼Žï¼Šï¼Š
ï¼Šï¼Žï¼Šï¼Šï¼Šï¼Žï¼Š
ï¼Šï¼Šï¼Žï¼Žï¼Žï¼Šï¼Š
ï¼Žï¼Šï¼Šï¼Šï¼Šï¼Šï¼Ž

) are something you'd encounter in the real world. In your puzzle, I couldn't find any instances of this in the existing cases. The closest I found was a hollow rectangular snowflake in the "All But One" test and the "connected-to-the-centre" snowflake in the "Simple Unique" validator.

If such instances don't exist, I'm not sure whether it would be a good idea to introduce them.

I also summarised the dimensions of the cases as follows:
h = w: 17 cases
h < w: 15 cases
h > w: 10 cases
(Total: 42 cases, i.e. 21 tests + 21 validators)

It's totally optional, but you could consider balancing this out a bit by adjusting existing cases or adding sky cells along the edges, without affecting the expected output. Since very few large cases contain empty edges, modifying those could be an easy fix.

In terms of naturally forming snowflakes, I can't say I have any idea but googling doesn't seem to provide any similar examples that I can see.

If you consider your case as a low resolution photo, it could appear that multiple separate snowflakes appear connected as 1 (e.g. *** ** for row 0), it would be possible for such a case to occur.

I can add them into the existing cases or include them in some new test/validators - Let me know your thoughts on this.

* I changed "Single Snowflake" and "Single Flakes" from h=w to h>w and added "Random test 3" as h>w. So it should be 15,15,14 now.

If we set aside the question of whether "a snowflake within a snowflake" can naturally occur, the pattern itself is an interesting addition to the puzzle. At the moment, the constraints don't explicitly forbid such inputs, so including them would still be consistent with the current specification.

That said, you could also choose to introduce a constraint that disallows this scenario.

If you do decide to include these patterns, here are two of the possible approaches:

1. If you think this scenario is noteworthy enough to merit players' attention, you could introduce it through a new pair of simple cases and then incorporate similar shapes into the final 3 to 5 pairs of existing cases.

2. If you feel this scenario isn't especially distinctive, you can simply integrate such shapes into the final pairs of existing cases without any special introduction.

I've added a couple in t/v 15-17 and also included a new test at the end.

I'll include your example in a simple test as there's still room and there is no harm in adding it just in case it does cause an issue for someone - I just need to copy and paste it all down ðŸ™ƒ

Sounds great!

Quick question while I'm going through the updated cases: are rotated and reflected versions of hollow snowflakes included in the revised cases? For example, if a 2x3 rectangular snowflake appears, would its 3x2 rotated counterpart be present in the same case? I might just be missing them, but I didn't spot any.
I don't think there are any in "Flakes in Flakes" but I've included a new test "Many Hollows" which includes that.
The cases look good to me. I assume you've made sure that all possible rotations and reflections for hollow snowflakes have been covered. ðŸ™‚

I included a variety but didn't include them all, so have ammended it to include them all.

If you think there is anything else then let me know. Thanks!
That's all from me for now. Many thanks!
